summary: Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a type of cancer that causes lesions (abnormal tissue) to grow in different parts of the body, including the skin, lymph nodes, mucous membranes, and other organs. These lesions are usually red or purple and are made of cancer cells, new blood vessels, and blood cells. KS can begin in more than one place in the body simultaneously.
causes: Human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8) also called Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV)
risk_factors: Weakened immune systems due to HIV
Weakened immune systems due to medicines taken after an organ transplant
Older men of Mediterranean or Eastern European Jewish heritage
symptoms: Red, purple, or brown skin lesions on the legs and feet
Lesions on the ankles or soles of the feet
Painful swelling due to pressure from lesions blocking lymph and blood flow
diagnosis: Imaging tests to check for spread
treatments: Adjusting dose or switching immunosuppressant medicines (for iatrogenic KS)
